list.title: Question 1
list.content: An arithmetic sequence has $u_1= 40$, $u_2 = 32$, $u_3 = 24$. - Find the common difference, $d$. [2] - Find $u_8$. [2] - Find $S_8$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The common difference is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d &= u_2 - u_1 \hspace{1.5em} \\[6pt]
  &= 32 - 40 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -8}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ with $n = 8$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} u_8 &= u_1 + (8-1)d   \\[6pt]
  &= 40 + (8-1)(-8) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -16}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(u_1 + u_n)$
with $n=8$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1em} S_8 &= \dfrac{8}{2}(u_1 + u_8) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{8}{2}(40 + (-16)) \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 96}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Consider an arithmetic sequence $2,6,10,14,\dots$ - Find the common difference, $d$. [2] - Find the $10$th term in the sequence. [2] - Find the sum of the first $10$ terms in the sequence. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have $u_1 = 2$ and $u_2 = 6$.
Hence the common difference is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d &= u_2 - u_1 \hspace{1.5em} \\[6pt]
  &= 6 - 2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 4}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ with $n = 10$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.8em} u_{10} &= u_1 + (10-1)d \\[6pt]
  &= 2 + (10-1)(4) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 38} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(u_1 + u_n)$
with $n=10$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{10} &= \dfrac{10}{2}(u_1 + u_{10}) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{10}{2}(2 + 38) \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 200} \end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 3
list.content: Only one of the following four sequences is arithmetic and only one of them is geometric. $$ \begin{array}{rcccccl} a_n &=& \dfrac{1}{3},\,\dfrac{1}{4},\,\dfrac{1}{5},\,\dfrac{1}{6},\,\dots &\,\hspace{4em}\,& c_n &=& 3,\,1,\,\dfrac{1}{3},\,\dfrac{1}{9},\,\dots \\[12pt] b_n &=& 2.5,\,5,\,7.5,\,10,\,\dots &\,\hspace{4em}\,& d_n &=& 1,\,3,\,6,\,10,\,\dots \end{array} $$ - State which sequence is arithmetic and find the common difference of the sequence. [2] - State which sequence is geometric and find the common ratio of the sequence.[2] - For the geometric sequence find the exact value of the sixth term. Give your answer as a fraction. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rclc|crcl}
  a_2-a_1 &\neq& a_3-a_2 &\,\hspace{0.5em}\,&\,\hspace{0.5em}\,& c_2-c_1 &\neq& c_3-c_2 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{1}{4}-\dfrac{1}{3} &\neq& \dfrac{1}{5}-\dfrac{1}{4} &&& 1-3 &\neq& \dfrac{1}{3}-1 \\[12pt]
  -\dfrac{1}{12} &\neq& -\dfrac{1}{20} &&& -2 &\neq& -\dfrac{2}{3} \\[12pt] \hline
  &&&&&&& \\
  b_2-b_1 &=& b_3-b_2 &&& d_2-d_1 &\neq& d_3-d_2 \\[12pt]
  5-2.5 &=& 7.5-5 &&& 3-1 &\neq& 6-3 \\[12pt]
  2.5 &=& 2.5 &&& 2 &\neq& 3
  \end{array} \vspace{1.2em}
  $$

  Hence
$\answer{b_n}$
is arithmetic and
$\answer{d = 2.5}$
- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rclc|crcl}
  \dfrac{a_2}{a_1} &\neq& \dfrac{a_3}{a_2} &\,\hspace{0.5em}\,&\,\hspace{0.5em}\,& \dfrac{c_2}{c_1} &=& \dfrac{c_3}{c_2} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{1/4}{1/3} &\neq& \dfrac{1/5}{1/4} &&& \dfrac{1}{3} &=& \dfrac{1/3}{1} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{3}{4} &\neq& \dfrac{4}{5} &&& \dfrac{1}{3} &=&\dfrac{1}{3} \\[12pt] \hline
  &&&&&&& \\
  \dfrac{b_2}{b_1} &\neq& \dfrac{b_3}{b_2} &&& \dfrac{d_2}{d_1} &\neq& \dfrac{d_3}{d_2} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{5}{2.5} &\neq& \dfrac{7.5}{5} &&& \dfrac{3}{1} &\neq& \dfrac{6}{3} \\[12pt]
  2 &\neq& 1.5 &&& 3 &\neq& 2
  \end{array} \vspace{0.95em}
  $$

  Hence
$\answer{c_n}$
is geometric and
$\answer{r = \dfrac{1}{3}}$
- Using the $n$th term formula $c_n = c_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 6$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  c_6 &= c_1r^{6-1} \\[8pt]
  &= 3\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)^{6-1} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{81}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Consider the infinite geometric sequence $4480$, $-3360$, $2520$, $-1890,\dots$ - Find the common ratio, $r$. [2] - Find the $20$th term. [2] - Find the exact sum of the infinite sequence. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have $u_1 = 4480$ and $u_2 = -3360$.
Hence the common ratio is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{3360}{4480} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= -0.75}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 r^{n-1}$ with $n = 20$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} u_{20} &= u_1 r^{20-1} \\[6pt]
  &= (4480)(-0.75)^{20-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx -18.9}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.3em} S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{4480}{1-(-0.75)} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= 2560}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Consider a geometric sequence with $a_1 = 8$ and $a_4=1$. - Find the common ratio, $r$.[2] Consider the following probability function for a random variable $X$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cb1c98a-b8ca-4dfb-b320-b777fc8e4063/images/d573dc05-cbef-4710-9eac-5d53fee67ac1/table.png) - Find the value of $k$.[4]
list.markScheme:
- Using the $n$th term formula, $a_n = a_1 r^{n-1}$, with $n=4$, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      a_4 &= a_1 r^3 \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\\\[8pt]
      r^3 &= \dfrac{a_4}{a_1} \\[7pt]
      r^3 &= \dfrac{1}{8} \\[6pt]
      &\hspace{-0.475em}\answer{r = \dfrac{1}{2}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Since the sum of probabilities must add up to 1, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      %ka_1+ka_2+ka_3+ka_4 &= 1 \\[8pt]
      k(a_1+a_2+a_3+a_4) &= 1   \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\[7pt]
      a_1+a_2+a_3+a_4 &= \dfrac{1}{k} \\[6pt]
      \dfrac{a_1(r^4-1)}{r-1} &= \dfrac{1}{k} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\[6pt]
      \dfrac{8\left(\frac{1}{16}-1\right)}{\frac{1}{2}-1} &= \dfrac{1}{k} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
      \dfrac{\frac{1}{2}-8}{-\frac{1}{2}} &= \dfrac{1}{k} \\[6pt]
      15 &= \dfrac{1}{k} \\[6pt]    
      &\hspace{-0.535em}\answer{k = \dfrac{1}{15}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Jeremy invests $\$8000$ into a savings account that pays an annual interest rate of $5.5$ %, compounded annually. - Write down a formula which calculates that total value of the investment after $n$ years. [2] - Calculate the amount of money in the savings account after: - $1$ year; - $3$ years. [2] - Jeremy wants to use the money to put down a $\$10\hspace{0.15em}000$ deposit on an apartment. Determine if Jeremy will be able to do this within a $5$-year timeframe.[2]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3d389660-6876-4d8b-af36-e47d89674806/images/768ccb37-8949-43dc-bc2a-9cc617ef40d9/eaedd006beb5ba238d9ad76a3a6f6101e049be71.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{FV} &= \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
  &= 8000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{5.5}{100\times1}\bigg)^{1\times n} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 8000\hspace{0.05em}(1+0.055)^n} \hspace{3em}{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - Substituting $n = 1$ in the formula $(1)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}

    &\answer{= \$8440}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Substituting $n = 3$ in the formula $(1)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \mathrm{FV} &= 8000\hspace{0.05em}(1+0.055)^3 \\[8pt]
    &=9393.9...\\[8pt]
    &\answer{\approx \$9390}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Substituting $n = 5$ in the formula $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.2em} \mathrm{FV} &= 8000\hspace{0.05em}(1+0.055)^5 \\[8pt]
  &\approx \$10\hspace{0.15em}456\end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Yes, Jeremy will be able to do this within a \(5\)-year timeframe.}}$

list.title: Question 10
list.content: An arithmetic sequence is given by $3$, $5$, $7,\dots$ - Write down the value of the common difference, $d$. [1] - Find - $u_{10}$; - $S_{10}$. [4] - Given that $u_n = 253$, find the value of $n$. [2]

    &\answer{= 21}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(u_1 + u_n)$ with $n=10$, we find

    $$

  \hspace{2.6em} 253 &= 3 + (n-1)(2) \\[6pt]

  $$

list.content: Consider the following sequence of figures. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/02c0ba8c-31f6-4ac2-be07-11a5cc2d5804/images/4cf394f8-a1d5-4b83-86b2-cc2e25134ee1/AA008.PNG) Figure 1 contains $6$ line segments. - Given that Figure $n$ contains $101$ line segments, show that $n = 20$.[3] - Find the total number of line segments in the first $20$ figures. [3]

- We have an arithmetic sequence with $u_1 = 6$, $u_2 = 11$ and
$u_3 = 16$.
  The common difference is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d &= u_2 - u_1 \\[6pt]
  &= 11 - 6 \\[6pt]

  $$

for $n$, we get

  $$

  $$

  &\answer{= 1070}\end{aligned}

list.title: Question 14
list.content: A $3$D printer builds a set of $49$ Ei$\text{f}$fel Tower Replicas in different sizes. The height of the largest tower in this set is $64$ cm. The heights of successive smaller towers are $95$ % of the preceding larger tower, as shown in the diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7c098710-c58c-4ef5-87d5-1552e9027719/images/e2ae24d8-0743-4825-b529-687c2f726965/AA724a.PNG) - Find the height of the smallest tower in this set. [3] - Find the total height if all $49$ towers were placed one on top of another. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 64$ and the
common ratio $r = 0.95$.
  Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n=49$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{49} &= u_1r^{49-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 64(0.95)^{49-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx 5.46 \text{ cm}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{u_1(1-r^n)}{1-r}$
with $n=49$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.9em} S_{49} &= \dfrac{u_1(1-r^{49})}{1-r} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{64\hspace{0.05em}(1-0.95^{49})}{1-0.95} \\[12pt]
  &\approx 1176.33 \\[16pt] 
  &\answer{\approx 1180 \text{ cm}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 56
list.content: The first three terms of a geometric sequence are $\ln x^9$, $\ln x^3$, $\ln x$, for $x > 0$. - Find the common ratio. [3] - Hence, solve $\displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^\infty 3^{3-k}\ln x = 27$. [5]

  $$

  &= 3^{3-n}\ln x\end{aligned}

  S_{\infty} &= \sum_{k=1}^\infty 3^{3-k}\ln x \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{u_1}{1-r} &= 27 \hspace{2.8em} \\[6pt]

list.title: Question 57
list.content: Consider a geometric sequence with common ratio $r$ such that $0 < r < 1$. - Show that $u_n - u_{n+1} = u_n(1-r)$.[2] A geometric sequence has a first term of 150 and a second term of 120. - Find the smallest value of $n$ such that $u_n - u_{n+1} < 1$.[3]

- Using the formula for the $n$th term of a geometric sequence, we have

  \begin{align*}
  u_n - u_{n+1} &= u_1r^{n-1} - u_1r^{n} \\[8pt]
  &= u_1r^{n-1}(1-r) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-4.5em}\tcbhighmath{u_n - u_{n+1} = u_n(1-r)}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- For a geometric sequence, we have $r=\dfrac{u_2}{u_1}$. Therefore $r = \dfrac{120}{150}$.
  Hence $u_1 = 150$ and $r=0.8$.
  We are solving the inequality $u_n - u_{n+1} < 1$. Using our result from part (a), we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_n(1-r) &< 1 \\[8pt]
  u_n(1-0.8) &< 1 \\[8pt]
  150(0.8)^{n-1}(0.2) &< 1 \\[8pt]
  150(0.8)^{n-1} &< 5
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Sketching the graphs of $y=150(0.8)^{x-1}$ and $y=5$ on the G.D.C. we look for the smallest integer value of $x$ for which $y<5\,$:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/99e5ce75-c1fd-4a36-8970-d0333d3c1521/images/91718d41-9bef-4be6-bce0-ddeb212c3f6a/aa986.PNG)


  The smallest integer greater than $16.2$ is $17$. Hence
  $\boxed{\text{The smallest value of } n \text{ such that } u_n - u_{n+1} < 1 \text{ is } n = 17.}$

list.title: Question 58
list.content: The first three terms of an infinite sequence, in order, are $2\ln x,\,\, q\ln x,\,\, \ln \sqrt{x}\,\,\, \text{ where $\ x > 0$.} $ First consider the case in which the series is geometric. - - Find the possible values of $q$. - Hence or otherwise, show that the series is convergent. [3] - Given that $q>0$ and $S_\infty=8\ln{3}$, find the value of $x$. [3] Now suppose that the series is arithmetic. - - Show that $q=\dfrac{5}{4}$. - Write down the common difference in the form $m\ln x$, where $m \in \mathbb{Q}$. [4] - Given that the sum of the first $n$ terms of the sequence is $\ln \sqrt{x^5}$, find the value of $n$. [8]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Given that the sequence is geometric, we have for the common ratio

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{q\ln x}{2\ln x} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{q}{2}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Similarly,

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    r &= \dfrac{u_3}{u_2} \\[8pt]
    \dfrac{q}{2} &= \dfrac{\ln \sqrt{x}}{q\ln x} \\[8pt]
    \dfrac{q}{2} &= \dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\ln {x}}{q\ln x} \\[8pt]
    \dfrac{q}{2} &= \dfrac{1}{2q} \\[8pt]
    q^2 &= 1 \\[8pt]
    &\hspace{-0.49em}\tcbhighmath{q= \pm 1}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Given that $r=\dfrac{q}{2}$, and $q= \pm 1$, we have $r = \pm \dfrac{1}{2}$. Hence $|r| < 1$.
    $\answer{\text{In both cases the series converges.}}$

- Given that $q>0$, $r = \dfrac{1}{2}$.
  Using the formula for the sum of an infinite geometric sequence, we~get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{u_1}{1-r} \\[10pt]
  8 \ln 3 &= \dfrac{2\ln x}{1-\frac{1}{2}} \\[10pt]
  8 \ln 3 &= \dfrac{2\ln x}{\frac{1}{2}} \\[10pt]
  8 \ln 3 &= 4\ln x \\[10pt]
  2\ln 3 &= \ln x \\[10pt]
  \ln 3^2 &= \ln x \\[10pt]
  \ln 9 &= \ln x \\[10pt]
  &\hspace{-0.54em}\tcbhighmath{x = 9} 
  \end{align*}
  $$

- 
  - First we find the common difference $d$ as follows

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    d &= u_2 - u_1\\[10pt]
    d &= q\ln x - 2\ln x \\[10pt]
    d &= (q-2)\ln x
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Similarly,

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    d &= u_3 - u_2\\[10pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &= \ln\sqrt{x} - q\ln x \\[8pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &= \ln x^{1/2} - q\ln x \\[8pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &=  \dfrac{1}{2}\ln x - q\ln x \\[8pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &= \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2} - q\bigg)\ln x \\[8pt]
    q-2 &= \dfrac{1}{2}-q \\[8pt]
    2q &= \dfrac{1}{2} + 2 \\[8pt]
    2q &= \dfrac{5}{2} \\[8pt]
    &\hspace{-0.535em}\tcbhighmath{q = \dfrac{5}{4}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Given that $d = (q-2)\ln x$ and $q = \dfrac{5}{4}$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    d &= \left(\dfrac{5}{4}-2\right)\ln x \\[10pt]
    &\hspace{-0.535em}\tcbhighmath{d = -\dfrac{3}{4}\ln x}
    \end{align*}
    $$


- Using the formula for the sum of $n$ terms of an arithmetic sequence, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  S_n &= \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d) \\[8pt]
  \ln \sqrt{x^5} &= \dfrac{n}{2}\left(2\hspace{0.1em}(2\ln x) + (n-1)\left(-\dfrac{3}{4}\ln x \right)\right) \\[8pt]
  \ln x^{5/2} &= \dfrac{n}{2}\left(\left(4\ln x + \left(-\dfrac{3}{4}\right)(n-1)\ln x\right) \right) \\[8pt]
  \dfrac{5}{2}\ln x &= \dfrac{n}{2}\left(4 - \dfrac{3(n-1)}{4}\right)\ln x \\[8pt]
  5 &= n\left(4 - \dfrac{3(n-1)}{4}\right) \\[8pt]
  5 &= 4n - \dfrac{3n(n-1)}{4} \\[8pt]
  20 &= 16n - 3n(n-1) \\[8pt]
  20 &= 16n - 3n^2 + 3n \\[8pt]
  3n^2 -19n +20 &= 0 \\[8pt]
  3n^2 -15n -4n +20 &= 0 \\[8pt]
  3n(n-5) - 4(n-5) &= 0 \\[8pt]
  (3n-4)(n-5) &= 0
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The solutions to the quadratic equation are $n=\dfrac{4}{3}$ and $n=5$.
  Since $n$ must be an integer, we have $\answer{n = 5}$

list.title: Question 59
list.content:
The $1$st, $5$th and $13$th terms of an arithmetic sequence, with common
difference $d$, $d \neq 0$, are the first three terms of a geometric
sequence, with common ratio $r$, $r \neq 1$. Given that the $1$st term
of both sequences is $12$, find the value of $d$ and the value of $r$.
list.markScheme:
The $1$st, $5$th and $13$th terms of the arithmetic sequence are $12$,
$12 + 4d$ and $12 + 12d$.
The first three terms of the geometric sequence are $12$, $12r$ and
$12r^2$ .
Hence we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
12 + 4d &= 12r \qref{(1)} \hspace{2.7em} \\[6pt]
12 + 12d &= 12r^2 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
$$

Dividing the equation $(1)$
by $4$ and the equation (2) by $12$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
3 + d &= 3r \qref{(3)} \hspace{1.7em} \\[6pt]
1 + d &= r^2 \qref{(4)}\end{aligned}
$$

If we subtract the equation $(4)$
from the equation $(3)$ and solve the resulting
$\text{equation}$ for $r$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
(3 + d) - (1 + d) &= 3r - r^2 \\[6pt]
2 &= 3r - r^2 \hspace{4.55em} \\[6pt]
r^2 - 3r + 2 &= 0 \\[7pt]
(r - 1)(r - 2) &= 0\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{7.9em} \answer{r = 2} \hspace{3em} \text{[since } r \neq 1\text{]}
$$

Hence, if we substitute $r = 2$ in the equation (4) and solve the
resulting equation for $d$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
1 + d &= 2^2 \\[6pt]
d &= 2^2 -1\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\answer{d = 3} \hspace{0.45em}
$$

list.title: Question 61
list.content: It is known that the number of trees in a small forest will decrease by $5$ % each year unless some new trees are planted. At the end of each year, $600$ new trees are planted to the forest. At the start of $2021$, there are $8200$ trees in the forest. - Show that there will be roughly $9060$ trees in the forest at the start of $2026$. [4] - Find the approximate number of trees in the forest at the start of $2041$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- The number of trees in the forest at the start of $2022$ will be

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{T}_1 &= 8200\times0.95 + 600 \hspace{2.8em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  The number of trees in the forest at the start of $2023$ will be

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.65em} \mathrm{T}_2 &= \mathrm{T}_1\times0.95 + 600 \\[7pt]
  &= \left(8200\times0.95 + 600\right)0.95 + 600 \\[6pt]
  &= 8200\times0.95^2 + 600(0.95 + 1)\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the number
of trees in the forest at the start of $2026$ will be

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{T}_5 &= 8200\times0.95^5 + 600\hspace{0.05em}(0.95^4 + 0.95^3 + 0.95^2 + 0.95 + 1) \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 9060}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The approximate number of trees in the forest at the start of $2041$
will be

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{T}_{20} &= 8200\times0.95^{20} + 600\bigg[\sum_{k=0}^{19}0.95^k\bigg] \\[2pt]
  &= 8200\times0.95^{20} + 600\bigg[\dfrac{1 - 0.95^{20}}{1 - 0.95}\bigg] \\[12pt]
  &\answer{\approx 10\hspace{0.15em}638}\end{aligned}
  $$

Squares with side lengths $n$ cm, $n^2$ cm, $n^3$ cm, $\dots$, where $0 < n < 1$, are drawn along [RS]. This process is carried on indefinitely. Find the value of $l$. [8]
list.markScheme:
- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$ with $u_1 = m = r$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.5em} 4 &= \dfrac{m}{1-m} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $m$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  4 - 4m &= m \\[12pt]
  4 &= 5m \hspace{1.6em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{m = \dfrac{4}{5}}
  $$

- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$ with $u_1 = n^2 = r$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.9em} \dfrac{25}{11} &= \dfrac{n^2}{1-n^2} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(2)$ for $n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  25 - 25n^2 &= 11n^2 \\[14pt]
  25 &= 36n^2 \\[10pt]
  n^2 &= \dfrac{25}{36} \hspace{2.9em} \\[6pt]
  n &= \dfrac{5}{6}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the sum of an infinite
geometric sequence formula $S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$
with
  $u_1 = r = n = \dfrac{5}{6}$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.3em} l &= \dfrac{5/6}{1 - 5/6} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 5}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 63
list.content: The first two terms of an infinite geometric sequence, in order, are $$ 3\log_3x,\,\, 2\log_3x,\,\, \text{where $x > 0$.} $$ - Find the common ratio, $r$. [2] - Show that the sum of the infinite sequence is $9\log_3 x$. [3] The first three terms of an arithmetic sequence, in order, are $$ \log_3x,\,\, \log_3 \dfrac{x}{3},\,\, \log_3\dfrac{x}{9},\,\, \text{where $x > 0$.} $$ - Find the common difference $d$, giving your answer as an integer. [3] Let $S_6$ be the sum of the first $6$ terms of the arithmetic sequence. - Show that $S_6 = 6\log_3 x - 15$. [3] - Given that $S_6$ is equal to one third of the sum of the infinite geometric sequence, find $x$, giving your answer in the form $a^p$ where $a,p \in \mathbb{Z}$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- The common ratio is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{2\log_3 x}{3\log_3 x} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{2}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{3\log_3x}{1 - 2/3} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{3\log_3x}{1/3} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 9\log_3x} \hspace{5em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.9em} d &= u_2 - u_1 \\[6pt]
  &= \log_3 \dfrac{x}{3} - \log_3x \\[6pt]
  &= (\cancel{\log_3x} - \log_33) - \cancel{\log_3x} \hspace{0.5em} \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= -1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with
$n=6$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.8em} S_6 &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2u_1 + (6-1)d) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2(\log_3 x) + (6-1)(-1)) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2\log_3 x - 5) \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 6\log_3 x - 15}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we solve the equation $S_6 = \dfrac{1}{3}S_{\infty}$ for $x$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  6\log_3 x - 15 &= \dfrac{1}{3}(9\log_3x) \hspace{3.6em} \\[8pt]
  6\log_3 x - 15 &= 3\log_3x \\[12pt]
  3\log_3x &= 15 \\[12pt]
  \log_3x &= 5 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x = 3^5} \hspace{2.5em}
  $$

list.title: Question 64
list.content: The first three terms of an infinite geometric sequence are $k-4,\,\, 4,\,\, k+2$, where $k \in \mathbb{Z}$. - - Write down an expression for the common ratio, $r$. - Hence show that $k$ satisfies the equation $k^2 - 2k - 24 = 0$.[5] - - Find the possible values for $k$. - Find the possible values for $r$. [5] - The geometric sequence has an infinite sum. - Which value of $r$ leads to this sum. Justify your answer. - Find the sum of the sequence. [5]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - The common ratio is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{4}{k-4}}\end{aligned}
    $$

    or

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    r &= \dfrac{u_3}{u_2} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{k+2}{4}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Hence we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.5em} \dfrac{4}{k-4} &= \dfrac{k+2}{4} \\[6pt]
    16 &= (k+2)(k-4) \\[10pt]
    16 &= k^2 - 2k - 8 \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{k^2 - 2k - 24 = 0} \hspace{7.05em}
    $$


- 
  - Solving the equation $k^2 - 2k - 24 = 0$ for $k$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    k^2 - 2k - 24 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    (k+4)(k-6) &= 0 \hspace{7.65em}\end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{k = -4,\, 6} \hspace{0.25em}
    $$

  - Evaluating $r = \dfrac{4}{k-4}$ for $k = -4,\, 6$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.5em} r &= \dfrac{4}{(-4)-4} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= -\dfrac{1}{2}}\end{aligned}
    $$

    and

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    r &= \dfrac{4}{6-4} \\[9pt]
    &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
    $$


- 
  - The infinite sum exists when $|r| < 1$.
We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \bigg|\hspace{-0.15em}-\dfrac{1}{2}\hspace{0.1em}\bigg| &= \dfrac{1}{2} < 1\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
$\answer{r = - 1/2}$
leads to this sum.
  - Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$,
    we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{(-8)}{1 - (-1/2)} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{(-8)}{3/2} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= -\dfrac{16}{3}}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 68
list.content: The sides of a square are $8$ cm long. A new square is formed by joining the midpoints of the adjacent sides and two of the resulting triangles are shaded as shown. This process is repeated $5$ more times to form the right hand diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1a91bc7f-44d0-4f6f-90c9-a7a3ec90646f/images/52204856-9803-492b-b040-827927d2cdbb/AA640.PNG) - Find the total area of the shaded region in the right hand diagram above. list.title: Question 69
list.content: Given a sequence of integers, between $20$ and $300$, which are divisible by $9$. - Find their sum. [2] - Express this sum using sigma notation. [2] An arithmetic sequence has first term $-500$ and common difference of $8$. The sum of the first $n$ terms of this sequence is negative. - Find the greatest value of $n$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have an arithmetic sequence $27,\, 36,\, 45,\,\dots,\, 297$ with
$u_1 = 27$ and $d = 9$.
  The number of terms in the sequence is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.8em} n &= \left\lfloor * \right\rfloor \dfrac{300}{9} - 2 \\[6pt]
  & = 31\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(u_1 + u_n)$ with $n = 31$, $u_1 = 27$ and
$u_n = 297$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} S_{31} &= \dfrac{31}{2}(27 + 297) \\[5pt]
  &\answer{= 5022}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Alternatively,
using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $n = 31$, $u_1 = 27$ and
$d = 9$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.6em} S_{31} &= \dfrac{31}{2}(2(27) + (31-1)(9)) \\[5pt]
  &\answer{= 5022}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since $u_1 = 27$, $d = 9$ and $n = 31$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} S_{31}  &= 27 + (27 + 9) + (27 + 2\cdot9) + \cdots + (27 + 30\cdot9) \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= \displaystyle{\sum_{n = 1}^{31}} (27 + (n-1)(9))} \\[5pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\text{or} \\[5pt]
  &\answer{= \displaystyle{\sum_{n = 1}^{31}} 9(n+2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $u_1 = -500$ and $d = 8$,
we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_n &< 0 \\[6pt]
  \hspace{4em} \dfrac{n}{2}(2(-500) + (n-1)(8)) &< 0 \\[6pt]
  n(-500 + (n-1)(4)) &< 0 \\[8pt]
  n &< 126 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence
the greatest value of $n$ is
$\answer{125}$

list.title: Question 70
list.content: A bouncy ball is dropped from a height of $2$ metres onto a concrete floor. After hitting the floor, the ball rebounds back up to $80$ % of it's previous height, and this pattern continues on repeatedly, until coming to rest. - Show that the total distance travelled by the ball until coming to rest can be expressed by $2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots$[2] - Find an expression for the total distance travelled by the ball, in terms of the number of bounces, $n$. [2] - Find the total distance travelled by the ball. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6c7dc2e3-7a08-4b87-96d6-7b2cab2e19ca/images/e45216f3-e445-40d8-b304-c2b6ab4f424b/866fc824efe482d8b182d4c5b9e109a2fdbd4aca.svg)


  Hence the total distance travelled by the ball until coming to rest
is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots}\qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- First we manipulate the equation slightly


$$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2em} [\text{sum of $n$ terms of $(1)$}] &= 2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + \cdots + 4(0.8)^{n-1} \\[14pt]
    &= \textcolor{blue}{-2 + 2} +\big[2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + \cdots + 4(0.8)^{n-1}\big] \hspace{1.3em} \\[8pt]
    &= -2 + \big[4 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + \cdots + 4(0.8)^{n-1}\big] \hspace{1.3em} \\[8pt]
    &= -2 + \textcolor{red}{\big[u_1 + u_2 + u_3 + \cdots + u_{n}\big]} \hspace{1.3em} \\[8pt]
    \end{aligned}
$$

Now we can see this is the sum of a geometric sequence  to $n$ terms with $u_1 = 4$ and $r = 0.8$
Using the formula $S_n = \dfrac{u_1(1 - r^n)}{1-r}$ for the sum of $n$ terms of a geometric sequence we get

$$
    \begin{aligned}
    &= -2 + \bigg[\dfrac{4(1 - 0.8^{n})}{1 - 0.8}\bigg] \\[8pt]
    &= -2 + 20(1 - 0.8^{n}) \\[8pt]
    &= -2 + 20 - 20(0.8^n)\\[12pt]
    &\answer{= 18 - 20(0.8)^n}
    \end{aligned}
$$


- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$ with
  $u_1 = 4$ and $r = 0.8$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &= 2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots \\[14pt]
  &= -2 + \big[4 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots\big] \\[8pt]
  &= -2 + \bigg[\dfrac{4}{1 - 0.8}\bigg] \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= 18 \text{ metres}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.content: The first two terms of an infinite geometric sequence are $u_1 = 20$ and $u_2 = 16\sin^2 \theta$, where $\text{\(0 < \theta < 2\pi\)}$, and $\theta \neq \pi$. - - Find an expression for $r$ in terms of $\theta$. - Find the possible values of $r$. [5] - Show that the sum of the infinite sequence is $\dfrac{100}{3 + 2\cos 2\theta}$. [4] - Find the values of $\theta$ which give the greatest value of the sum. [6]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - The common ratio is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{16\sin^2 \theta}{20} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{4\sin^2 \theta}{5}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Since $0 < \theta < 2\pi$ and $\theta \neq \pi$, we have
$\sin \theta \neq 0$.
    Hence we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    0 < \sin^2 \theta &\leq 1 \\[9pt]
    0 < \dfrac{4\sin^2 \theta}{5} &\leq \dfrac{4}{5} \hspace{2.8em}\end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{0 < r \leq \dfrac{4}{5}}
    $$


- Using the double-angle formula for cosine, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \cos 2\theta &= 1 - 2\sin^2\theta \\[6pt]
  2\cos 2\theta &= 2 - 4\sin^2\theta \\[6pt]
  3 + 2\cos 2\theta &= 5 - 4\sin^2\theta \hspace{4em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$,
  we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{20}{1 - \dfrac{4\sin^2 \theta}{5}} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{100}{5-4\sin^2 \theta} \\[15pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{100}{3 + 2\cos 2\theta}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The greatest value of the sum is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{100}{3 + 2(-1)} &= 100 \hspace{6.8em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence,
solving the equation $\cos 2\theta = -1$ for $\theta$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2\theta &= \pi,\, 3\pi \hspace{2.5em}\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{\theta = \dfrac{\pi}{2},\, \dfrac{3\pi}{2}} \hspace{1.5em}
  $$

list.title: Question 74
list.content: Bill takes out a bank loan of $\$100\hspace{0.15em}000$ to buy a premium electric car, at an annual interest rate of $5.49$%. The interest is calculated at the end of each year and added to the amount outstanding. - Find the amount of money Bill would owe the bank after $10$ years. Give your answer to the nearest dollar. [3] To pay off the loan, Bill makes quarterly deposits of $\$P$ at the end of every quarter in a savings account, paying a nominal annual interest rate of $3.2$%. He makes his first deposit at the end of the first quarter after taking out the loan. - Show that the total value of Bill's savings after $10$ years is $P\bigg[\dfrac{1.008^{40}-1}{1.008-1}\bigg]$. [3] - Given that Bill's aim is to own the electric car after $10$ years, find the value for $P$ to the nearest dollar. [3] Melinda visits a different bank and makes a single deposit of $\$\hspace{0.05em}Q$, the annual $\text{interest}$ rate being $3.5$%. - - Melinda wishes to withdraw $\$8000$ at the end of each year for a period of $n$ years. Show that an expression for the minimum value of $Q$ is $$ \dfrac{8000}{1.035} + \dfrac{8000}{1.035^2} + \dfrac{8000}{1.035^3} + \cdots + \dfrac{8000}{1.035^n}. $$ - Hence, or otherwise, find the minimum value of $Q$ that would permit Melinda to withdraw annual amounts of $\$8000$ indefinitely. Give your answer to the nearest dollar. [6]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d244213c-76e5-48b7-b9ee-a00f3bf9ce88/images/5edcedf3-7a6a-44da-b760-9ca13ffe649f/8d43689548a3d16e00609e684b76b38f90c0c20a.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.8em} \mathrm{FV} &= \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
  &= 100\hspace{0.15em}000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{5.49}{100\times1}\bigg)^{1\times10} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{\approx \$170\hspace{0.15em}653} \hspace{8em}{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The number of time periods in $10$ years is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  n &= (4)(10) \\[6pt]
  &= 40\end{aligned}
  $$

  The total value of Bill's savings after $10$
years is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{FV} &= P + P\bigg(1 + \dfrac{3.2}{100\times4}\bigg) + P\bigg(1 + \dfrac{3.2}{100\times4}\bigg)^2 + \dots + P\bigg(1 + \dfrac{3.2}{100\times4}\bigg)^{39} \\[9pt]
  &= P + P(1.008) + P(1.008)^2 + \cdots + P(1.008)^{39} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = P$ and the
common ratio $r = 1.008$.
Hence, using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{u_1(r^n - 1)}{r - 1}$ with $\text{\(n = 40\)}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{FV} &= S_{40} \\[12pt]
  &=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{P\bigg(\dfrac{1.008^{40} - 1}{1.008 - 1}\bigg)} \hspace{8em}{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $(1) = (2)$ for $P$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.45em} 170\hspace{0.15em}653 &= P\bigg(\dfrac{1.008^{40} - 1}{1.008 - 1}\bigg)  \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{P \approx \$3637}
  $$

- 
  - We have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d244213c-76e5-48b7-b9ee-a00f3bf9ce88/images/50d1a7e3-b079-421d-9f26-30cd46ff690b/7fa99aa4ecafd8974b214fde355c840e109f39ef.svg)


    Hence the amount of money in Melinda's account after $n$ years
is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} \mathrm{FV} &= \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
    &= Q\bigg(1 + \dfrac{3.5}{100\times1}\bigg)^{1\times n} \\[12pt]
    &= Q(1.035)^n\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence we deduce

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    Q(1.035)^n &= 8000 + 8000(1.035) + 8000(1.035)^2 + \cdots + 8000(1.035)^{n-1} \\[12pt]
    Q &= \dfrac{8000\big[1 + 1.035 + 1.035^2 + \cdots + 1.035^{n-1}\big]}{1.035^n} \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{Q = \dfrac{8000}{1.035} + \dfrac{8000}{1.035^2} + \dfrac{8000}{1.035^3} + \cdots + \dfrac{8000}{1.035^n}} \hspace{4em}
    $$

  - We have an infinite geometric sequence with the first term
$u_1 = \dfrac{8000}{1.035}$ and the common ratio
$r = \dfrac{1}{1.035}$.
Hence, using the sum of an infinite geometric
sequence $\text{formula}$ $\text{\(S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}\)}$,
we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} Q &= \sum_{k=0}^\infty \bigg[\dfrac{8000}{1.035}\bigg]\bigg[\dfrac{1}{1.035}\bigg]^k \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{\frac{8000}{1.035}}{1 - \frac{1}{1.035}} \\[15pt]
    &\answer{= \$228\hspace{0.15em}571}\end{aligned}
    $$
